Round numbers thing is really interesting. The Bitcoin UTXO pricing strategy first got me looking at this, but you've given me a nice reminder to look at how this crops up elsewhere.

I think August '24 caught a lot of people off guard. Was interesting to me that this day had even larger liquidations than the 'Liberation Day' period, given that price went much lower then. Conclusion I'd draw is that the market is better prepared for deep downside if it's expected, than sudden volatility nobody was expecting.
The realised volatility is measured by the standard deviation in log returns on a rolling 7-day window
fwiw you can also trade this as a realised - implied vol strategy

1/ how do you measure volatility as it's a trailing indicator.

small suggestion that we did on rates trading desk - use intraday High - Low as you can relate that to Mean Absolute Deviation ... assuming geometric brownian motion you can map that back to an implied vol

Who are the lenders in this situation?

I put in 1 BTC, and I flash borrow 120k crvUSD from who? The pool?

Afterwards, I have the LP and I have debt that I need to pay off.

In that case they've just given me 240k crvUSD in exchange for 120k crvUSD and 1 btc?

And then (somehow this is the part I don't understand), it can maintain that 2x leverage as prices go up and down

And maintaining 2x lev consistently on a short enough time frame is approx similar to having x^2 exposure

Which will hedge out having a normal sqrt(x) lp exposure?
